title: N.C. girl battling cancer meets Taylor Swift
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest N.C. girl battling cancer meets Taylor Swift For nearly 15,000 fans, Wednesday, October 21 was a day they had been anticipating for a long time. Post to Facebook N.C. girl battling cancer meets Taylor Swift For nearly 15,000 fans, Wednesday, October 21 was a day they had been anticipating for a long time.  //on.11alive.com/1RZtDeC   Join the Conversation To   N.C. girl battling cancer meets Taylor Swift Taylor Swift Concert Preview WFMY News 2 USA Today Network Benjamin F Powell, WFMY-TV, Greensboro, N.C. 4:29 p.m. EDT October 22, 2015 Greensboro girl, Olivia Dunn, with Taylor Swifft at 1989 tour stop in Greensboro on Oct. 21, 2015 (Photo: Olivia Dunn) 1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
GREENSBORO, N.C. -- For nearly 15,000 fans, Wednesday, October 21 was a day they had been anticipating for a long time. 
Pop singer Taylor Swift performed live at the Greensboro Coliseum. But for one little girl from Greensboro — the show is a dream come true. 
10-year-old Olivia Dunn has been through more hard times than most people go through their entire lives. Earlier this spring, she was diagnosed with Ewing sarcoma Stage 4 bone cancer. Doctors misdiagnosed her with juvenile rheumatoid arthritis almost two years ago. 
Since then, she's been fighting for her life. She's lost her hair from chemotherapy — next up is radiation. She's been through more than most of us have in our life. Olivia is excited to forget the pain & have fun tn! @WFMY pic.twitter.com/J10nkpaqX5 — Ben Powell (@benpowelltv) October 21, 2015 
She hasn't been able to live a normal life because her bones are too brittle and she's constantly in pain. A few months ago, Olivia found out she would get to meet her idol, Taylor Swift. 
Olivia Dunn and her mother, Tara. (Photo: WFMY News 2) 
On Wednesday night, just like her favorite Taylor Swift song, her "Wildest Dream" came true. Olivia got to meet the pop icon before the concert. 
"It has been really tough and very hard and it's not easy," said Dunn. "I probably won't be focusing on that tonight because I'm just going to be so happy." 
Her dream didn't end on Wednesday. 
The Make-a-Wish Foundation is sending Olivia and her family to Disney World for a nine day trip later this week. Oh, yes we are!
